questions.question: Question 1: What is the pinna made up of?
questions.explanation:
The pinna and the external auditory canal are made up of yellow elastic cartilage. It is also called 
the auricular cartilage.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 25-year-old woman undergoes a rhinoplasty procedure to correct a deformity of her nose. 
Auricular cartilage is harvested from her right pinna. Which of the following sites cannot be 
used to harvest the cartilage?
questions.explanation:
Incisura terminalis cannot be used to harvest cartilage as it is devoid of cartilage. It is the part of the pinna between the tragus and the crus of helix. Being devoid of cartilage, 
the incision for endaural approach for ear surgery can be made here. The lobule is also devoid of cartilage. Hence, it is the safest site for piercing. The parts of the pinna are: 19 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is true regarding the skin over the pinna?
questions.explanation: The skin over the pinna is loosely adherent on the medial or cranial side. Hence, it is pinchable. The skin is firmly adherent to the perichondrium on the lateral side and is non-pinchable.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the length of external auditory canal?
questions.explanation:
The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm. It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts: • Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm • Inner bony part- 16mm 20 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: You are an intern asked to do an otoscopic examination of a young adult. In which direction 
will you pull the pinna to visualize the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation:
The pinna has to be pulled upwards, backwards and laterally to visualise the tympanic membrane. 
This is done to bring the bony and cartilaginous parts of the external auditory canal in alignment. The inner bony part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially. The outer cartilaginous part is directed upwards, backwards, and medially.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is true about the external auditory canal?

options.a: Outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 2/3rd is bony
options.b: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony
options.c: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous
options.d: Outer 2/3rd is bony and inner 1/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.explanation:
The outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous (8mm) and the inner 2/3rd is bony (16mm) in the external 
auditory canal. 21 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with otitis externa develops parotitis. You suspect that the infection has spread 
through the fissures of Santorini. Which of the following best describes this fissure?

options.b: Connection between middle ear and pharynx
options.c: Connection between Inner ear and middle ear

questions.explanation:
Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory 
canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the 
canal or vice versa. The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke which acts as a pathway for 
the spread of infections and tumours to the deep lobe of the parotid.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is true regarding the external auditory canal?

options.a: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony part
options.b: Furuncles are seen in the cartilaginous part
options.c: Fissures of Santorini are present in bony part and permits parotid and superficial mastoid
options.d: Isthmus is present at junction of cartilaginous and fibrous part

questions.explanation:
Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the 
canal since hair is confined to the outer canal. Skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.

questions.question: Question 9: What are ceruminous glands?
questions.explanation:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles & 
participate in wax production. Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound 
cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted. Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll’s glands, 
and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands. 22 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is true regarding isthmus?

options.a: It is just lateral to the petrotympanic suture.
options.b: It is at the bony cartilaginous junction of EAC.
options.c: It is the narrowest part of ear canal.

questions.explanation:
The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal (EAC). EAC measures about 24 mm long, cartilaginous part forms the outer one-third (8 mm) and bony 
part forms two-third (16 mm) of the canal. Isthmus is situated 6 mm lateral to the tympanic 
membrane in the bony part of the EAC. Foreign bodies that go beyond the isthmus are difficult to 
remove and are called impacted.

questions.question: Question 11: You observe a normal-looking tympanic membrane on otoscopy. What is its colour?
questions.explanation: The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tympanic membrane?

options.b: It is derived from all 3 germ layers
options.c: It seperates external from middle ear

questions.explanation: Peripheral parts are more mobile than the central part where the handle of the malleus is attached The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers. It has 3 layers – • Outer epithelial layer from ectoderm • Middle fibrous layer from mesoderm • Inner mucosal layer endoderm.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is false about the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation:
23 
Sold by @itachibot The tympanic membrane has a thickness of 0.1mm. The dimensions of the tympanic membrane are • Length: 9-10mm • Width: 8-9mm • Area: 90 mm2 • Subtends an angle of 55° with horizontal The medial (inner) surface is convex and the lateral surface is concave. The most depressed part of 
its concavity is called the umbo, to which the tip of the malleus is attached. Image: Right tympanic membrane

questions.question: Question 14: What is the other name for Shrapnell’s membrane?
questions.explanation:
Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane. Pars flaccida is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and the 
anterior and posterior mallear folds.

questions.question:
Question 15: During an otoscopic examination of a patient, where will the cone of light be seen on the 
tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation:
A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the tip of malleus (umbo) to the periphery in the 
anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. 24 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.explanation:
Greater auricular nerve (C2,C3) supplies most of the medial surface and posterior portion of

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient develops tingling and numbness along the upper part of the medial surface of the 
pinna. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
The upper part of the medial surface of the pinna is supplied by the lesser occipital nerve. Nerve

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient coughs when removing excess cerumen from the ear. This is due to the stimulation 
of which of the following nerves?
questions.explanation:
Reflex cough is due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus. It can occur when cleaning or 
during an examination of the ear. Nerve

questions.question: Question 19: What is Arnold's nerve?
questions.explanation:
Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) is also called Arnold’s nerve or Alderman's nerve. Tympanic branch of CN IX is also called Jacobson’s nerve. Sensory root of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg and carries secretomotor fibres 
to the lacrimal gland and salivary glands, and brings fibres of taste and general sensation. 27 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following cranial nerves do not supply the tympanic membrane? 17 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) does not supply the tympanic membrane. It is supplied by: • Lateral surface - • Anterior half by auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3) • Posterior half by auricular branch of vagus nerve (CN X). • Medial surface - • Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's nerve) CN IX.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 25-year-old patient presents with bleeding from his ear following a road traffic accident. 
Which of the following could be its reason?
questions.explanation:
A temporal bone fracture can cause bleeding from the ear as it is related to the roof of the middle 
ear and the external auditory canal. The relations of the external auditory canal are: • Superior - Middle cranial fossa • Inferior - Parotid gland • Anterior - Temporomandibular joint • Posterior - Mastoid air cells and facial nerve.

questions.question: Question 22: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.explanation:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve 
(Arnold's nerve). Arnold's nerve supplies the concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface. It also 
supplies the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal. Scratching or mechanical 
stimulation of the ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough (ear-cough 
reflex/otorespiratory reflex). The image below shows the nerve supply of the pinna: Causesofreferred otalgia
